awd_titl_txt: Investigating quantum critical and topological dynamics in f-electron materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Abstract: Lanthanide- and actinide-based materials comprise a rich reservoir of new and novel properties of fundamental scientific interest and potential applications in current and future technologies.  These f-electron quantum materials are found in the periodic table of the elements starting with lanthanum and actinium. Here we search for new quantum materials based on lanthanide and actinide elements. This specifically includes materials containing cerium, praseodymium, samarium, europium, ytterbium and uranium. Detailed investigations of the physical properties and underlying physics will be pursued with the primary goal of characterizing the  striking phenomena of fundamental interest and relevance to technology. These studies are expected to yield new materials that will advance technological applications. This includes thermoelectric cooling and electrical power generation, magnetocaloric refrigeration, magnetic sensors, magnetic information storage, quantum computing, and high temperature superconductivity for electronics, magnetic resonance imaging, and the generation, transmission, and storage of electrical energy.  This program contributes to the education and training of postdoctoral scholars and graduate and undergraduate students, some of which are from underrepresented groups.  The PI's and their group members are involved in community outreach activities, including laboratory tours for high school and undergraduate students, science demonstrations at local elementary schools, and popular lectures.

Technical Abstract: Lanthanide- and actinide-based f-electron quantum materials comprise a rich reservoir of correlated electron phases and phenomena, including valence fluctuations, heavy fermion behavior, Kondo insulator behavior, quantum criticality, non-Fermi liquid behavior, metal-insulator transitions, unconventional superconductivity, magnetic and charge order, and topological phenomena. Competing interactions can be "tuned" by varying non-thermal control parameters such as chemical composition, pressure, and magnetic field, leading to complex phase diagrams containing a multitude of these correlated electron phases and phenomena. Of particular interest are unconventional superconductivity, exotic magnetic phases and non-Fermi liquid behavior in low temperature physical properties that occur in the vicinity of a quantum critical point where a second order phase transition (usually, antiferromagnetic) is suppressed to 0 K. The objectives of the proposed research are to characterize these extraordinary phases and phenomena, determine the conditions under which they are formed, identify underlying microscopic mechanisms, and test appropriate theories. The approach involves materials synthesis (particularly single crystals) and measurement of the transport, thermal, and magnetic properties of these materials as a function of temperature, composition and magnetic field. This is complemented with quasiparticle dynamics measurements using ultrafast optical spectroscopy, providing a powerful means to interrogate and temporally disentangle charge, spin, lattice, and orbital degrees of freedom.  A broad range of correlated f-electron materials such as filled skutterudite compounds and the Kondo insulator samarium boride, a candidate for a correlated electron topological insulator, and its alloys will be investigated.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Basic research and technology:

In this project, the physical properties of correlated d- and f-electron quantum materials were studied in order to gain insight into the electronic interactions which produce phenomena of fundamental interest and relevance to technology. The approach involved synthesis of materials (particularly single crystals) and measurement of their electrical, thermal, and magnetic properties as a function of temperature, chemical composition, pressure, and magnetic field. The knowledge gained through this work will provide scientific underpinnings that could lead to technological advances in a number of areas; e.g., thermoelectric cooling and electrical power generation, permanent magnets, magnetocaloric refrigeration, magnetic sensors, magnetic information storage, quantum computing, and applications of superconducting materials with high critical temperatures, critical fields, and critical current densities. Applications of superconductivity impact several important sectors, including basic science (e.g., superconducting magnets for research, particle accelerators), transportation (e.g., magnetic levitation of high-speed trains), energy (e.g., generation, transmission, and storage of electrical energy), medical diagnostics (MRI magnets, SQUID magnetic sensors), and electronics. This work has contributed to the training of a new cadre of scientists and technologists who will be involved in the development of new technological applications.

The investigations that were carried out yielded important information concerning correlated electron and topological phenomena in a variety of quantum materials. Examples include unconventional superconductivity in UTe2, information concerning the nature of the so-called “hidden order” phase in the correlated f-electron compound URu2Si2, the identity of which has eluded researchers for more than three decades, the discovery of a conducting surface state, which may exhibit ferromagnetic order, in the correlated d-electron semiconductor FeSi, three-dimensional T-x-P (T = temperature; P = pressure) phase diagram for the URu2-xFexSi2 system in very high magnetic fields, revealing a unique relation between the applied magnetic field H and the temperature To below which the “hidden order” phase occurs.

Education, training and professional development:

The principal investigators and their group members were involved in community outreach activities, including laboratory tours for high school and undergraduate students and their parents, science demonstrations at local elementary schools, and popular lectures. The study of correlated d- and f-electron quantum materials in our laboratories serves to train the next generation of condensed matter and materials physicists who will contribute to the academic, industrial, and/or government sectors in their careers. Postdoctoral researchers and graduate students gain expertise in a broad range of technical skills. Undergraduate students, many of whom become interested in our laboratories through the classes we teach and the group’s outreach efforts, comprise a significant portion of the laboratory’s membership. These undergraduates include student interns that work in the lab during the summer, such as students from Mexico under the ENLACE program, UCSD students enrolled in independent study, and UCSD underrepresented minority students, such as McNair Scholars. Most undergraduates who work in our laboratory go on to receive advanced degrees.

Society and the general public:

During the course of this project, our groups were engaged in community outreach activities, including laboratory tours for high school and undergraduate students and their parents, science demonstrations at local elementary schools, and popular lectures given by the principal investigators and their group members. Certain aspects of the research performed under this grant were communicated to the general public through various websites, popular lectures, and outreach activities.

Collaborative research:

An important aspect of the field of correlated electron research is its inherent interdisciplinary nature, requiring the cooperation of experts performing complementary types of measurements. This collaborative network forms the backbone of an international research community. Our laboratories have a proven history of developing and strengthening scientific collaborations on a international scale with universities and research institutes. Through these cooperative efforts, the laboratory’s materials synthesis and properties measurement capabilities were made available to the broader scientific community, both on and off-campus. Our groups have benefited from the specialized facilities, equipment, and instrumentation available through large research centers such as the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory at Florida State University and Los Alamos National Laboratory, and neutron or photon scattering facilities available in the US national laboratory system. Measurements were also performed abroad at facilities in Canada, China, Europe, and Japan.
